Here are a few ideas on financial markets that will make you think more critically:  1. Tech will continue to outperform - many people think the tech sectors' recent outperformance means we are headed towards another Dot Com bust, but the deflationary aspect of technology, along with the global adoption now available for these products, will probably keep the outperformance going for years to come.  2. Historical stock valuations are likely wrong - investors used to allocate to stocks simply to capture a potential reward, but now a good portion of investors are also allocating to stocks to hide from higher inflation levels. This leads to a new monetary premium on stock valuations that will render historical valuations less useful.  3. The 60/40 portfolio will die - the legacy thought process was that this allocation mix could protect investors, but we saw over the last few years that stocks and bonds both went down, so the theory didn't work as intended. The new generation, which has less trust in central banks, will shun bonds and the largest Treasury buyers (foreign central banks) are also showing less interest.  4. All assets will become digital over time - the transition from analog assets to electronic CUSIPs created trillions of dollars in value. The shift from electronic to digital will be even bigger (ex: stablecoins already proving this) and an asset like bitcoin will eventually have higher market cap than gold.   5. Countries will have to retrain workers - wages have no chance of keeping up with inflation, so countries will have to make large investments in retraining workers. They will move too slowly and entire generations will suffer. The best path would be to redesign the education system from the ground up, but that is also the hardest path.   6. There will be a renaissance of small business globally - historically these small businesses were physical locations on Main Street, but now they are ecommerce stores, content creators, and digital agencies. As labor creates these businesses, there will be little capital invested, so the returns captured by Main Street business investors in past decades will disappear.   7. Developed nations will continue electing radical economic thinkers - the internet open-sourced information and the countries in the worst economic positions will take a flyer on disruptive politicians. You can see Bukele in El Salvador and Milei in Argentina as examples, but these innovators have better chance of turning these economies around than traditional politicians.   8. Demographics will become less important signal for investors - the demographics data has always told the story of economies and markets, but that will change with the rise of robotics. You won't need to measure demographics of humans, but rather the production lines of robot manufacturers. Whichever economy has the most robots, wins.   9. Inflation targets will increase - central banks find themselves in a bad position and have no choice but to stick with loose monetary policy over the long-term. They will increase their inflation targets to 3% or more, so they can continue to present a sense of control over economies, although the true inflation number will always be higher than reported.   10. Traditional economic data will be exposed for inaccuracy - legacy investors have been using data that is flawed to make decisions. The collection is filled with issues (ex: we send physical humans into grocery stores to report prices), the methodology is inaccurate (ex: weighted baskets can't ever reflect accurate inflation), and the conclusions are erroneous (ex: every person has a different inflation number). Getting new data will change the way capital is allocated & be the foundation for the future.   -------  This list is not comprehensive of everything that will change, but this is a decent overview of various evolutions I have been thinking about.   I would love to learn what you think about these, while also hearing what other ones you think are important. Bank for International Settlements (BIS) --|  "Central counterparties (CCPs) are key players in financial markets, holding $1.3 trillion in liquid assets as of June 2023. The holdings are highly concentrated in the eight largest CCPs, mainly based in Europe and the United States. Most of these liquid assets are 'cash' – ie deposits at central banks, reverse repos and unsecured bank deposits – and government bonds, which CCPs receive as collateral for the transactions they clear. This collateral improves systemic resilience by shielding CCPs from counterparty risk. But it also imposes liquidity demands on market participants that, occasionally, could worsen financial stress during flight-to-safety episodes or lead to destabilizing margin spirals. The dual role of government bonds as both collateral and underlying assets for CCP-cleared derivatives introduces 'wrong-way' risk that can exacerbate these spirals". The latest IMF report shows that 20 of 39 Kenyan banks were accessing the discount window.   Here are a few notes on the discount window:  —What is a Discount Window? This is a tool used by central banks to provide short-term loans to eligible financial institutions, such as commercial banks when they need additional liquidity. It is a form of lender of last resort, meaning that it is a safety net for institutions that are unable to borrow from other sources. —Loan Terms: Short-term, usually overnight, at higher-than-average rates (the discount rate) to discourage excessive use. The central banks decide on loan approval based on genuine needs. —Roles of Window: Ensures liquidity in the financial system and maintains financial stability by aiding temporarily struggling institutions. Also allows central banks to influence monetary policy via the discount rate (By raising or lowering the discount rate, the central bank can encourage or discourage borrowing by banks, which in turn affects the money supply and interest rates in the broader economy.) —Liquidity Sources: Banks have access to several liquidity sources: interbank market, horizontal repos, vertical repos, and the central bank's discount window. In Kenya, the discount rate is usually the Central Bank Rate + 400bps while the Interbank rate oscillates between the bands of CBR ± 250bps —Discount Window Stigma: Stigma arises when banks are hesitant to use the discount window, even when they may be facing financial difficulties because they fear that borrowing from the central bank could signal to the public and other market participants that they are in financial trouble or facing liquidity problems. —Mitigating Stigma: To mitigate this stigma, central banks offer anonymous borrowing to reduce stigma. This is one reason why it is hard to know which banks have tapped into the window. Some central banks, like the US one, want to force all banks to use it at least once a year to reduce the stigma.  In short, the use of the discount window should be encouraged not discouraged.

You often see me talk about market internals. What are they? How do you use it for your advantage?  Market internals refer to a set of technical indicators and data that provide insight into the overall health and condition of the financial markets, specifically the stock market. These indicators help traders and analysts gauge the underlying strength or weakness of the market beyond just looking at stock prices. Market internals typically include the following:  1. Advance-Decline Line: This indicator tracks the number of advancing (rising) stocks minus the number of declining (falling) stocks in a given market index, like the S&P 500. A rising advance-decline line suggests broad market strength, while a declining line indicates weakness. 2. Up Volume and Down Volume: These measure the total trading volume of stocks that are up (gaining) and down (losing) for a particular trading session. High up volume relative to down volume can indicate bullish sentiment, and vice versa. 3. New Highs and New Lows: These indicators count the number of stocks reaching new 52-week highs and new 52-week lows. A higher number of new highs suggests market strength, while an increasing number of new lows can indicate weakness. 4. Tick Index: The tick index measures the number of stocks on an uptick (their last trade was at a higher price than the previous trade) minus the number of stocks on a downtick (their last trade was at a lower price than the previous trade). It can provide intraday insights into market sentiment. 5. Put-Call Ratio: This ratio compares the total number of put options (bearish bets) to call options (bullish bets) traded in the options market. A high put-call ratio may suggest increased fear or bearish sentiment among traders. 6. The recent green light given to spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has sent shockwaves through the financial markets.   But what does this mean for you, and what could the future hold for the world of cryptocurrency investment ?    Let's explore ↓   What is a Bitcoin ETF ? --------------------------------  A Bitcoin ETF is an exchange-traded fund that offers investors exposure to the price movements of Bitcoin.   Unlike owning the cryptocurrency directly, investors can buy and sell shares of a Bitcoin ETF on a stock exchange, making it a more accessible investment vehicle for those who may be hesitant to directly invest in Bitcoin.  Here are the main points on how Bitcoin ETFs work:  ------------------------------  1️⃣. Bitcoin ETFs track the price of Bitcoin by holding either actual BTC or derivatives like futures contracts that follow price movements.   2️⃣. These ETFs are accessible through regular stock markets, making them more appealing to a wider range of investors who may be familiar with traditional investing but cautious about diving into crypto exchanges.   3️⃣. The investment process is simplified as investors can buy and sell shares in the Bitcoin ETF through conventional brokerage accounts, bypassing the need for digital wallets and cryptocurrency exchange accounts.   4️⃣. As Bitcoin ETFs are traded on traditional exchanges, they are subject to regulatory oversight, offering an added layer of security and legitimacy compared to direct crypto investments.  ----------------------------------------------------------------  The SEC has approved the listing and trading of a number of spot Bitcoin ETF shares, including applications from major financial firms such as BlackRock, Ark Investments/21Shares, Fidelity, and VanEck. This approval is expected to lead to a surge in trading activity, with billions of dollars' worth of shares already being traded.  What's Next ? ----------------------------  The approval of these ETFs is likely to trigger intense competition among issuers for market share, with analysts estimating that Bitcoin ETF flows could eventually surpass $10 billion.   This development is expected to further institutionalize Bitcoin as an asset class and provide both institutional and retail investors with easier access to the cryptocurrency.  In summary, the approval of spot Bitcoin ETFs represents a major step forward for the cryptocurrency industry, potentially opening up new opportunities for investors while also introducing new considerations and dynamics to the market.

Trading success is built on the bedrock of discipline and patience. In the ever-changing landscape of financial markets, the ability to avoid impulsive decisions and adhere to a well-thought-out trading plan becomes paramount. Let's delve into seven actionable tips that not only cultivate patience but also enhance discipline for traders aiming for long-term prosperity.  1️⃣ Define Your Trading Plan with Precision: Begin with a meticulously crafted trading plan. Specify entry and exit criteria, risk tolerance, and overall strategy. This detailed roadmap not only provides clarity but also serves as a constant reference point to deter impulsive deviations. If your strategy dictates a specific price level for entry, patiently wait for the market to reach that level before executing your trade.  2️⃣ Exercise Selective Trade Execution: Patience is a virtue, especially in waiting for high-probability setups. Resist the temptation to jump into every market move. By being selective, you preserve your mental capital and ensure each trade is a well-considered decision. Avoid entering trades simply due to market noise; instead, patiently wait for setups aligning with your strategy.  3️⃣ Master the Art of Waiting: Discipline is honed by mastering the art of waiting. In the midst of market fluctuations, refrain from acting on impulse. Wait for signals, patterns, or confirmation that align with your predetermined strategy. Patience means not succumbing to the urge to exit a trade prematurely during minor market fluctuations.  4️⃣ Implement Progressive Risk Management: Discipline extends to risk management. Implement progressive risk controls, adjusting position sizes based on your evolving account balance. This prevents impulsive decisions during volatile periods and ensures adherence to your risk management plan. Patience involves resisting the desire to increase position sizes during winning streaks, staying consistent with your risk management strategy.  5️⃣ Review and Reflect on Trades: Regular reviews are indispensable for refining your trading approach. Analyze both successful and unsuccessful trades, seeking patterns in your decision-making process. This reflective practice builds discipline and provides invaluable insights for future endeavors. Patience is reflected in taking the time to review trades thoroughly, identifying areas for improvement.  6️⃣ Utilize Trading Simulations: Enhance discipline through simulated trading environments. Practice patience by utilizing demo accounts or backtesting tools like simulators. These platforms allow you to experience various market scenarios without financial risk, fostering a disciplined mindset. Patience is exercised by traders who diligently practice in simulated markets before deploying strategies in real-time.  7️⃣ Cultivate Emotional Resilience: Patience intertwines with emotional resilience. Disciplined traders understand that market conditions can test emotions. Cultivate patience by acknowledging the inevitability of market fluctuations and maintaining composure during challenging times. Patience in the face of a losing streak involves refraining from impulsive revenge trading and sticking to the established plan.  Discipline and patience are not just virtues; they are the cornerstone of successful trading. By incorporating these seven tips into your trading routine, you'll navigate the markets with a steady hand, making decisions rooted in strategy rather than emotion.  #Trading #patience #tuesdayvibe #education
